category.catDesc: Frank: a Sequel to Frank in Early Lessons
Harrington, a Tale; and Ormond, a Tale
Tomorrow; or the Dangers of Delay

div.p:
"I hate you"! and pray now my dear what in the name of fortune put
that into your head? pray why should I hate Miss Fanny Robinson? Because
she has uniformly shewn me more love, attention and kindness than
any friend of my own age ever showed me before & Because those years
ago she prefered me to twenty other Girls out of whom she has to chuse?choose
Because after a three years absence she still continues to think
of me & think of me with partiality? or because where no one liked
me she soon defended me? when I was half Blind & could
not read, she read to me, & because & since I have been idle & negligent and
have not written to her this four months she has written me three
kind Letters! If you think all or any of these are good Reasons for
hating a person You may conclude that I hate you, but if on the
Contrary you rather think them Reasons for liking a person; you
may conclude that I like you - and so I leave you to your conclu-
-sionsconclusions - Now I must answer another of your Questions, if I
have not answered it compleatly already, viz. whether I am alive
or no? - And so you flatter yourself that I am dead do you!
No, Love, don't , I pray you, for I am likely to live and love
you long! I been afflicted with a disease for which I
am sure you will heartily pity me. I have been troubled with a
disease called the Lazy's - which has prevented my writing to you
tho' I often wished it - But the truth is, this continued frost & severe
weather is very apt to throw freeze the spirits & bring on the Lazy's -
now that the thaw is coming I expect they will thaw too &
restore me to the Active's - the words "If youhate me" operated
almost as fully as a thaw I assure you - for you see that I have
taken a preposterously large sheet of paper to pay my debts:
three in one - I I wrote to you an answer to your first
Letter since my silence, in which you complained of my Gravity
& seemed to have taken it not a little Ill that I hinted something
about a womanly style - "There is some difference; said you, between
a Girl who has but just left school & one who has left it for two or
three years" & then you stopt, & begged pardon for raging so much
to one "who was so much older than yourself." Lord my dear
you talk to me as if I was old enough to be your great grandmother
& pray how old now do you think I am - Why I shall be Seventeen
next new years day, when I beg you will drink my health & &c. recollect
it is not Seventy but Seventeen - I say I had written an answer
to this letter of your's a great while ago but fearing that it was
still too grave I tore it & determined to wait till time should
make you more, on me less so - but after your third expostulatory
letter & the conclusion "I am sure you hate" me I could hold out no
longer & so resolved to write to you immediately whether I was
too grave or not for you - So drink my health in a Bumper
on new year's day & forget all this - Whenever we meet I flatter
myself my dear Fanny that my Gravity will be no damp to
your gaiety; you will find me full an ready to laugh as
you can be to make me laugh - I recdreceived. Miss Hartley's
letter but she may abide a bit for an answer - you may convert
my Lazy's into any other disease you please for an excuse
for me - I am glad you are acquainted with Miss Keresford
she is an agreeable young Woman & an old acquaintance
of mine: pray what does she say of me? I used to write to
her, but I had some suspicions that she shewed my letters
to people who did not like me, & indeed I thought she did
not like me much herself & so I left off: I suppose you mean
Miss Judith Beresford about 19 or 18 or perhaps 20 is not she? -
when you write to her; give my comptscompliments.. to her - & tell me how
she likes me &c - the Lady I mean sings remarkably well -
Mary Brine was a very pretty little Girl of 9 or old when
I knew her - Tell me did they talk of the of Ashbourne
and of another family of Beresford who live -
Have you heard any thing lately of Miss Cave or of Miss Burlton
that was on of poor little Miss Ogalire? - What family is Miss Hashleys?
a memorable one? or a Gentleman's? I want to know something
more about her & her connexionsconnections? before I write to her - for
you know if I write to her, when I come to England I must
visit her & if her, her family & Relations & therefore I wish
to know what they & whether my Lady Robinson is ac-
-quaintedacquainted with them or no? - pray don't think from
this that I am proud; I don't want to know whether they
are rich & great, but whether they are sensible & well bred
whether in short they are such as you like - I am not
so fond of forming connexionsconnections as a Lady my mother was
acquainted with; a Miss Baldwin, who when she was asked
why she married? answered To raise my Consequence and
strengthen my connexionsconnections!! Was not her husband much
obliged to her! - This Lady I think or some of her fellows
it was who on coming from London to a country Town wanted
to shew off to the Country folks & began to run on about
the crowd of Rich she recdreceived.. "Lord Bless me, says she, its quite mon-
-strousmonstrous, I was actually hurried alive, To death, such reviling &
such a confusive hurry I protest to you. it was nothing from
morning to Night but eailsin & eail out! -
Now we talk of Eails have you heard of the evil of the two Conways
& Captain Whiteworth? The French King has clapped them
into the Bastile for an Intrigue with the french Queen -
Ah rare King & Queen! I wonder whether ever a french CaptnCaptain
in the grand Monarque's Service dare so much as speak
to our Queen / -

Now I will tell you what we are about here - We have just
read Mr. Berquin's Ami des Enfans - a charming collection of
little plays - if you have not seen them I conjure you to read them
immediately for I am sure they will delight you & anybody
Robinson Have you read Mad.meMadame de Genlis' Viellies du Chateau
I have not - We have had her Annals of Virtue in the house
this twelvemonth & not one of us has had the Courage to read
them! - No thoughts of publishing my Translation - But
my Father prefers the thoughts of an Original Work upon
Education, including the marks upon Madme.Madame de Genlis
Rousseau &c seen a Book of my friend Mr. D
upon Educa andford & Her Son - I hear she
patronized it it to the Royal Children to rea
pray read it for my Sake & tell me how you like it
But above all don't forget Berquin, for you really wi
charmed with him - I think of writing some plays
English - & I am just beginning a tragedy founded
an anecdote in the Life of Hyder Ali - Mirza his Brother.
in Law falls in Love with the Daughter of an European
whom he (Saiza) has thereupon raised to be his favorite
This favorite is very ambitious wants to persuade Mirza
to marry his Daughter Theana & by that means to raise
his family & himself to the throne - he leads Mirza into all
sorts of dissipation, squanders away the public
treasure & at length persuades him to betray & revolt
against Aider his friend, Brother in Law, &c and Sovereign
in order to become an independent prince & to have the
Liberty of marrying Theana & settling the crown upon her
father - He has a Battle with Aider Ali, conquers
him - but the natural goodness of his heart makes him
sensible of the deepest Remorse for having betrayed his
Benefactor - & allied himself with a villain - for he now
begins to see the character of his favorite & suspects Theana
of Ambition instead of trusting to her pretended Love -
He applies to a knowing King for his Alliance -
The King replies, that tho he is himself an Enemy to Aider -
he will never join with a Traitor against - This is the
exact historical Answer - The proud & generous mind
of Mirza is stung to the Quick by this Reproach -
He is haunted by remorse - detests his favorite -
struggles between his repentance & his passion for Theana
Theana has an interview with him, melts him into
Love - she orders a Triumph to be prepared as is the
custom in India after a Victory - orders it to be proclaimed
throughout his Kingdom that the next Hour shall make
Theana his Wife and Queen in defiance of the Ancient
laws of the Nation which do not allow him a Queen
but only a Mistress - She is transported with joy -
forgets her usual Humility - betrays the Transport of
Successful ambition rather than of grateful love -
beseeches to give her a ring which he wears on
his Finger as her nuptial Ring - This Ring was the gift
of Aider to Mirza in their former days of friendship - The
circumstances awakens his stifled Remorse - he flings
from Theana - conquers his passion - The feast is ready
the people wailing - The Favorite comes to see for the
King to lead them to his daughter, his Theana, her Kings
Bride & Queen - but the King is gone - left the palace -.
thrown himself at the feet of Aider - abandoned his Mistress
& his Kingdom as a prof of his Repentance - implores Aider
forgiveness - Aider forgives him generously - I can no more!

postscript.p:
I know not the Cootes of Dublin
My father is ssing for a
-cated seat in the County at this Ins-

Am not I good to write you so long a
letter Taxed to death as I am!
